doc.title: Robam Appliance (A)
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Robam Appliance A Sequential improvement in 2Q but not encouraging enoughRobam Appliance A Sequential improvement in 2Q _2025-08-29

passages.text: Reiterate Rating: NEUTRAL | PO: 21.30 CNY | Price: 19.79 CNY

Robam's revenue/NPAT was \(- 2.6\% / - 6.3\%\) in 1H25, or \(+1.6\% / + 1.9\%\) in 2Q25, sequentially improved from \(- 7\% / - 16\%\) in 1Q. However, we think such re- acceleration is not encouraging enough, compared with other white goods peers'. Visibility in 2H remains challenging and low, suggesting the sequential recovery may not be sustained (especially with high 4Q base). It announced a \(66\%\) interim dividend payout, up from \(62\%\) in 1H24.

We maintain our cautious outlook on Robam's long- term growth drivers amid persistent headwinds from weak property transactions, intensifying online competition, and margin dilution from development of new product categories. We lower our 2025/26E EPS by \(2.1\% /1.1\%\) , but maintain our PO of RMB21.3 with rolled over valuation anchor to average 2025/26E from 2025E. We think its full- year revenue growth guidance of \(5\%\) appears challenging, implying \(11\%\) growth required in 2H. The stock currently trades at \(11x\) forward P/E with a \(6\%\) dividend yield, a balanced risk- reward profile. Reit. Neutral.

Sequential revenue acceleration in 2Q was largely attributable to recovering online sales (1Q - \(17\%\) , 2Q + \(0.2\%\) ) and a narrowing decline in toB sales (1Q - \(22\%\) , 2Q - \(18\%\) ; thanks to development of kitchen cabinet business), which accounted for \(34\% /14\%\) of sales. GPM expanded \(137bp\) to \(47.8\%\) in 2Q25, mainly due to tailwinds from falling raw material costs, supply chain reforms and channel mix change (reduced exposure to low- margin toB). SG&A/revenue was - \(52bp\) , with +46bp in S&D/revenue offset by - 98bp in admin expense/revenue and R&D/revenue. As a result, OPM was +189bp to \(15.5\%\) and OP + \(16\%\) . However, lower investment income and interest income weighed on bottom- line, limiting NPAT growth to \(2\%\) . Operating cash flow grew \(23\%\) YoY in 1H25, thanks to lower bill receivables on declining toB.

Company DescriptionRobam, started in 1988, is China's No.1 name in kitchen appliances, in terms of value shares in range hood and stove (according to China Market Monitor). The brand focuses on the high-end segment with ASP about \(40\%\) higher than the industry average. The company has expanded its product offerings to other kitchen appliances such as sterilizers, ovens, steam ovens and dish washers, leveraging its strong brand recognition.

Investment RationaleWe reckon Robam's leading position in kitchen appliances, a small but fast- growing industry compared with large white goods. It is also well- poised to benefit from consumption upgrade, but cyclicality and unfavorable channel mix could weight on near- term growth and cap re- rating potential. We believe structural challenges of channel mix shift could remain to hinder on margin outlook.

We cut our 2025/26E estimates by \(2.1\% /1.1\%\) to reflect results. We maintain our PO of RMB21.3, based on a blend of P/E and DCF. Our P/E- based value is RMB21.2, on unchanged 12x P/E after rolling over our valuation anchor from 2025 to 2025/26 EPS. The PE multiple is close to historical trough during the property downcycle. Our DCF- based value is RMB21.4, derived from \(11.4\%\) WACC, \(0.93x\) beta and a lower terminal growth rate of \(2\%\) (vs. \(2.5\%\) previously) to reflect increased uncertainty over the long- term growth outlook.

To reflect both the near- term growth and the long- term outlook, we use a blend of P/E and DCF to derive our PO of RMB21.3. Our DCF- based value is RMB21.4, derived from \(11.4\%\) WACC, \(0.93x\) beta and \(2.0\%\) terminal growth rate. Our P/E- based value of RMB21.2 is based on \(12x\) 2025/26E P/E, which is close to historical trough during the property downcycle.

Upside risks are faster- than- expected property recovery leading to higher volume growth of kitchen appliance, direct ASP hikes, faster e- commerce growth, lower- than- expected cost inflation, and higher operating leverage. Downside risks are weaker- than- expected property market further dragging down kitchen appliance volume growth, slower- than- expected mix upgrade, surging cost inflation, and higher A&P spending on penetrating into new sales channels.
